If I HAD to stay in Playa again I would book Pueblo Escondido. Although Shangri La was nice, it was just not the type of place I am used to staying at.

Reviews.Title: “Perhaps some new info re. beach front”
Reviews.Author: bantusbantus
Reviews.Content: Like many of you, we read the reviews before booking. No matter how nice a place you stay at, seemingly there's always someone who has a terrible experience...which always leaves me wondering "who are these people"? So I think it's important to know your source in this case: my wife and I have stayed at 5 star hotels and your basic holiday inns and have had great experiences at both and are just as happy at both, so hopefully this will lend some credibility We stayed here during the first week of Feb 09. Weather was high 70's to low 80's and windy (and we live in the midwest so that's saying something). You can defintely stand to bring some long sleeves and jeans/pants at night. We stayed in 1C which is a beach front bungalow which we were very enamored with based on the pictures we saw on the site. And here is the perhaps new piece of info that I didn't read anywhere on trip advisor on this property...and I read about 100. The beach front bungalows are LITERALLY spitting distance from the water. Very cool in the day time but at night, what might seem charming at first (sound of waves crashing into the sand) is down right loud! If you're a light sleeper, it will keep you up. The shutters on the screens don't completely keep the wind out so it does get pretty nippy at night when you're sleeping. If I had to do it again, it would be much cheaper to stay in an ocean front room -- you would be plenty close to the water but the sound would be blocked by other buildings so it would be much more peaceful. You can get single huts (ie. not at 2 story) in the ocean front and you're maybe 30 yards further from the water....big deal. So that's my biggest advice...save money and skip the ocean front bungalow. Ours was directly next to the public passage onto the beach. No issues at all with that. Locals stayed in their spot and the security was always around to make sure if you were on the properties' chairs, you belonged there. Security was unobtrusive. As others have stated, the property ground and beach was kept up daily. Random things: We got the same scoop on the whole closing thing...no one really seems to know for sure. People do get out early to put out their orange towels. There was always room but sometimes I had to walk a whole 20 or 30 extra feet away from my hut to put them down... 2:1 from 5 to 6 pm at the bar near the lobby. They were nice enough (I read the bar tenders weren't too friendly). I wasn't looking for a new lifetime pal, just a beer, so it worked for me. There's access to computers and the net if you need it. Pools aren't heated and are cold. The pool near the breakfast place tends to have the kids if they are around but on the upside, when it's really windy yet sunny on the beach, this area tends to be less windy for sunnying Just like many people have said, breakfasts are good. Dinners are hit and miss. Some are good, some are ok. They put out the menu everyday in the lobby so you can check it out in advance. I like good food so we ate out on 5th Ave 1/2 the time 5th ave is about a 5-10 min walk as others have said. You are completely at one end and it will take you quite a while to walk the whole length. Some nice stuff, lots of junk and tourista stuff. Price negotiate like a fiend...I looked at a pair of snake boots: $750 to start and after some talking and walking away we were down to $200. It's astounding how simply walking away changes the "best price". I'd advise changing your money before you leave home or when you get here to pesos. The exchange rate was 13 to 1 but you don't seem to get that when you buy things. 30 cents on the dollar here and there isn't a big deal, but after a week or so, it adds up. If you want to save, convert. If you can't be bothered, you'll probably spend a bit more -- that's what we did but I wish now we had converted since I'm cheap! Attention steak lovers (ie. Ruth's Chris not Ponderosa). Best steaks on 5th ave is a restaurant called SUR Argentina...it's on 5th and about 12th. On the right side if you're coming from the hotel. Spendy but really good steaks like you'd have at home. If you come from a no smoking city, prepare to appreciate your home town. People smoke. Cool funky coffee shop just past the hotel as you're heading towards 5th ave on the left. Tucked away. Check it out Back to the hotel: rooms are plain like all have said. Bed is plenty comfy. No head board in 1C. No TV, radio, phone, clock etc. They supply one very large bottle of water per day. I was a bit concerned re. bugs from reading reports. One night we had 1 roach which I'm sure some people will read and say I am so not staying there, but that was it. Nothing else in a week. And hey, you're right on the beach. If you saw a bug at the 4S you'd right it off as bad luck and that's what we did. If you do stay in a beach front bungalow, 1C is huge. Speaking of huge, the pictures of the beach are deceiving. We were staying here predominantly b/c of the nice beach. It is nice, but is no where near as deep/wide from water's edge to bungalows as the pictures suggest...these must be old or pre storm. The beach is more than adequate, but its just not as big as the pix show. There's a massage hut if your'e interested. Dive shop is a 100 yards away. As for picking a side, Caribe v.s. Adventura...we obsessed on this for a while and just decided to have them pick for us. We were on Caribe and retrospecitvely, that was good...lots of foot traffic between the bungalows in Adventura that are close to/on the way to the bfast place. I wouldn't like the traffic. Oh yeah, the racoons. I thought when I read that, that someone was joking. Then I saw a picture on another post and figured they were serious......then I saw 2 of them in the brush while at dinner at the hotel one night. Not bothering anyone but maybe that's a good reason to go to 5th ave?! Took one tour while there: a combo of Tulum and Cobas ruins and a trip to Playa Paraiso beach. $70 per person. Left at 0840 and home by 6 or so pm. Not a bad deal if you're looking to see if the whole ruin thing is your deal. Unfortunately, you don't get to spend enough time at either ruin and the beach was insanely windy (very nice though if you're looking for a huge beach with white sand). The concierge desk has a book of many many tours you can sign up for. Tulum has a beautiful beach so it could conceivably be cheaper to take a cab back and forth and spend the day there. Lunch is included. From what we heard, the tour to Chichen is the same way: not enough time there with a a very long bus ride. There's a safe in your room too. Overall, nice place for a beach vacation. Be careful what you ask for re. "being right on the water". That's what we wanted and we got it big time and that proved to be awfully loud. Cheaper and just as nice in ocean front. This is not a pamper experience. If that's what you want ala 4S (and boy it is nice when you have it), you won't find that here. But if you want to hang out on a nice beach and be close to shopping and some tourista stuff, this will do the job. $80-90 one way from the airport. $50 going back.

Reviews.Title: “A heavenly getaway”
Reviews.Author: chelsea341
Reviews.Content: This was my first trip to Mexico and Playa del Carmen and my only regret is why I waited so long. Shangri-La Caribe couldn't have been a more perfect choice for what my husband and I were looking for - six days of sun and total relaxation and freedom from work, commitments, TV's, and laptops. From the moment we checked in and proceeded to enter the oasis of greenery that makes up Shangri-La's grounds, I could feel the stress of my daily routine and the flight disappear. ( It usually takes me a couple of days to unwind). The helpful and friendly gentleman that took our bags set up two hammocks on our porch and we were ensconced in them reading books within 1/2 hour of our arrival. We stayed in the Pueblicito garden section which are the least expensive rooms, but very pleasant, basic yet comfortable, with a tiled bathroom and open shower and a cute porch with the hammocks and a clothesline to hang the beach towels you will be given during your stay. It was also extremely quiet with proximity to the bar, where we got to watch the inauguration, and had the chance to partake in the nightly happy hour with good bartenders and excellent, strong margaritas almost every evening. The grounds were immaculate and it was apparent that the staff worked very hard at maintaining it as so - I got up at 6AM a couple of mornings to catch the sunrise and they were already out there sweeping aroung the pool and pathways. They were always cheerful and eager to please. There are two pools which were always uncrowded, the water was a bit chilly but once you got in it was fine. Breakfast was excellent and plentiful, especially the poached eggs which I ordered a few times and were the best I've ever had, and the oatmeal. (of all things!) I read unfavorable reviews on the dinner here but we ate there every night and thought the food just fine - half the time it was buffet style with a Mexican or Caribbean theme. All the waitstaff were conscientious and quick. For lunch, we went to La Cuerva de Chango twice which is right down the road from the hotel, and found the food there inexpensive and delicious - the salsas, dipping sauces, and breads worth it alone. The beach and water were perfect - immaculate, with plenty of lounges and relatively uncrowded, with security walking around to ensure only guests were in the immediate area. Non-guests were on the beach also but nearer the shore and were not a bother anyway. I took long walks along the shore and felt Shangri-La had the nicest beachfront of all. I had asked about the rumor of the closing but I was told it probably wouldn't be happening for at least the next year or two. With all the ugly, half vacant condo developments in the area it would be a real shame to tear something down that is beautiful and seems to be working well just to build another condo complex or generic all inclusive. With that in mind I am already planning my schedule for another trip to to Shangri-La next winter!

Reviews.Title: “Best Hotel In Playa Del Carmen”
Reviews.Author: jeffrese
Reviews.Content: My wife and I went for a long weekend getaway from the cold and dark of New York City in mid winter. What a great little hotel. We had a private thatched roof hut nearly right on the beach. $220/night with breakfast and dinner included. This is a small hotel so you aren't packed on the beach with hundreds upon hundreds of people. The food was good and the staff was great. By the end of the weekend they all knew our name. It probably helped that we were tipping at breakfast and dinner. You aren't required to tip but you should. Relatively it is a small amount to you but a huge amount to them and they will appreciate it and take extra good care of you. We didn't do much besides sit on the beach and walk into town for cocktails before dinner. I did go fishing one morning and that was great too. In shore, 4 hours caught a ton of stuff including an 8 foot bull shark, drinks and food included $200. It was the perfect weekend get away. And they have very good security. I would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Good resort-a little overpriced”
Reviews.Author: Chili5
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Shangri-la over New Year's Eve. The rooms were very clean and cute. The maid service was exceptional. However, it seems to me that the other staff did not care much if you were there or not. I guess we are used to getting great personal service, and this resort did not hold that standard. We ended up only eating breakfast there and went in town for dinner. Let me say that you must go to Carboncito's, El Fogon, and 1847. They were all great and we had great service at all of these places. While my attitude is a little neutral on the service at the hotel, I will say that we did enjoy our stay...we just thought there would be more personal service at such a small resort. We plan on returning to Playa in June and staying at a Boutique Hotel. Loved Playa, but want to love our hotel as well!

Reviews.Title: “Happy Hour Heaven”
Reviews.Author: LittleMoonie
Reviews.Content: We stayed here as the first part of our honeymoon and couldn't have wished for a better start. The staff were super friendly, so welcoming and great fun. The rooms were spotlessly cleaned every day and well appointed. The complex is also located on the best part of the beach in Playa del Carmen. Make sure you don't miss out on the happy hour drinks - a real highlight! Overall, highly recommended and good value for money.

Reviews.Title: “A small paradise”
Reviews.Author: fverhoog
Reviews.Content: This surely is an excellent hotel; too bad it's going to be torn down as of April 2009 to make room for a big ugly new hotel. It is situated on the beach front. The rooms are actually little tropical huts that sort of form a village, connected by sandy gardens and walkways. It boasts two pools and two excellent restaurants. Breakfast is as it should be with lots of fresh fruits and eggs-any-style-you-want. The best thing about the hotel probably is that it is situated about 10min walk from the center of Playa del Carmen. Other people told us that a new club just opened in the center (Coco Bongo), which keeps all the guests of the hotels in the vicinity awake until 7am! Don't wanna walk to the center everyday? Grab a cheap cab for 4 or 5 USD. The center of Playa del Carmen is very appealing, with lots of great restaurants and bars, and nice shops. It's a fairly new tourist area (approx 8 years old), so no shabby buildings or anything. Not compared to Cancun, which nowadays is a horrible, busy city near the beach, with daytime traffic jams and permanent loud noise.

Reviews.Title: “Just FANTASTIC!!”
Reviews.Author: Jakse
Reviews.Content: This hotel i simply perfect. Rooms are very nice, clean and everythings works. The hotel area is tropical, friendly and very very well kept. Beach is perfect, food is great, and most of all the staff is the friendliest and most smiley like staff I have ever met. Very high and friendly service. Thank you to them all:-)

Reviews.Title: “Perfect, just like every review!”
Reviews.Author: JeffmoTX
Reviews.Content: Every review of Shangri-la was right on the money - amazing stay after 2-3 trips that were below our expectation at other resorts. We stayed in a beachfront suite and it was roomy and the private front porch was what made the trip. We had happy hour drinks each night and dinner at the hotel many of the days. We got Ice each morning and some snacks and drinks from the local market right up the street. $5 cab ride to downtown Playa and we went in 2 nights and had some decent meals but none much better than what we had at the hotel. We saw the same staff at breakfast and dinner most every day which was nice and they always remembered us and where we liked to sit - very nice touch. Only small complaint was the air condition in the beachfront rooms are not very strong as we like to sleep cold. We were either outside or right under the vent to stay cool since we took the trip in August. All in all everything was perfect, very much worth the money and the best trip we have yet to take!

Reviews.Title: “I want come back”
Reviews.Author: Cabaliero
Reviews.Content: I’m from Russia and I have visited Mexico the first time in my life. I went to this country for my honeymoon and selected Playa Del Carmen city because I and my wife needed perfect beach and sea, not night life as in Cancun. By internet I realized that sea and beach in Playa Del Carmen are better that in Cancun. Shangri-La Caribe hotel I found by tripadvisor.com and there is no one opinion from other russian tourists. It was also the first time when I used this web site to looking for residence. So there was only one way – just to believe all that I have found on this resource. And now my trip in the past and what I can to say? All my expectations are not only come true. Shangri-La Caribe become one of the best hotels in the world I have ever seen. The main reasons for this high rating are very, very beautiful hotel design both in case of interior of the rooms and exterior, comfortable and beautiful white sand beach and also are very friendly staff. Hotel is placed right on beach in the beginning of the city and at in five minutes walk from the beginning of 5th avenue – central tourist street in Playa Del Carmen with a lot of restaurants, café and gift shops. The hotel buried in verdure and this is one of its advantages. The hotel is not big. We are lived at Caribe section and there is about one and half minute walk to the beach. Let me repeat, that it is very, very beautiful hotel with beautiful beach of white sand and motton blue sea with plane sand bottom. I recommend this hotel to honeymooners and other who want to go to beautiful and quiet place at Carribean sea. Unfortunaly recreation depends on people who are living in hotel with you. We had been in Shangri-La for two weeks. During first ten days hotel was half empty and it’s was fine. We can always find free beach chairs, tables at restaurant, etc. But on eleven day a lot of Americans arrived and hotel became full. Americans with children different ages – from infants to teens. They were very noisy. It was irritated. Moreover there are appeared problems to find not occupied table in restaurant, place on beach or billiard table at the bar. I read that there is a little boringly in the hotel due to lack of televisions in rooms. One man suggested to take portable video players, radios, etc. But I want to say that there is no necessity for these things. However you can take notebook because there is unlimited wireless internet access in the reception hall and in the bar only for 20 pesos (about 1,5 dollars). There is no internet in rooms. Now my trip in the past and there is one more thing that I want to tell you: I realized that I’m missing for my Shangri-La Hotel room and this beautiful friendly place of the world. P.S. You are welcome to any questions about Shangri-La and Playa Del Carmen city.

Reviews.Title: “Low key, Low stress, Warm staff, Great beach”
Reviews.Author: CPS200
Reviews.Content: I just got back today from a 4 day stay at Shangri-La Caribe. The hotel is awesome if you want a real low key holiday. There are no TVs or telephones in the room. Each room is in a bungalow and has its own outside sitting area. My room was clean, had two firm queen beds, a view of the ocean, Mexican tile floors and bathroom and ,most importantly, it had air conditioning. It was rustic and charming and all very well done. The room comes with breakfast and dinner included. The breakfast was actually a lot better than what I thought it would be. I did not eat dinner at the hotel during the stay (Playa Del Carmen's restaurants are about a 10min walk from the property). The single best thing about the resort is their beach. There are plenty of chaise lounges. They don't have the crowds that all the other places have. It's very quiet, uncrowded and they have waiter service that brings food and drinks to your chaise! If you want to relax and enjoy the beach and you don't need to be pampered too much-this is the place.

Reviews.Title: “Vacation Accomplished”
Reviews.Author: rzk4sb
Reviews.Content: Staff - friendly, accommodating, and helpful. We had to swtich rooms after the first night because of noisy neighbors and the staff obliged without hesitation. Room - spartan yet clean. No TV/Phone which was fine for me. Wi-fi only accessible in the lobby. Partial ocean view was exactly as promised with a 30 second walk to the surf. The pounding of the waves set us to sleep everynight. Location to Town - 5 minute walk to all the action of 5th avenue. Otherwise very quiet and serene. "Mini-super" markets within reach for necessities. Food - above average for all-inclusive. Didn't really partake in dinners, only breakfast and occassional lunch (not included) Bar - ask for a margarita with 1800 tequila, the well tequila is alright, caprhinas were a little lime-y Beach - beautiful sand/view/water with ample furniture. Hammocks on each palapa porch are a nice way to unwind. Services - Dive shop was good, Cenote dives were life-changing. HP and Emilio are awesome divemasters. Maid service was well done. Guests - Nice mix of Europeans, Americans, and Argentinians. Regrets - would have liked to have wi-fi access from my room but no big deal overall. ***Playa Del Carmen in General*** *Dining - ate mostly on 5th avenue for dinner, overall very good food with Metropolitan prices. Karma bagels on 5th is a very good lunch option. Stray away to 10th avenue for cheaper venues. *El Diez (El 10) - Good cheap Argentinian food, watch out for the hot red sauce *Di Vino - Ate here twice. Once was the best meal in Playa, the other was not so good. *Sur - Expensive Argentinan but well done with friendly staff *Yaxche - Fantastic Mayan food with friendly service, get the Tikin-Xic fish and you won't be disappointed *Maya Ajual - Good food and atmosphere, kinda touristy *Media Lune - Good food and atmosphere, kinda touristy *Shopping - When will the Mexicans learn that cat-calling to people will not increase foot traffic in their stores? It's alright as many are hilarious and honest about their wares *Drinks - Grab a drink at Basico on 5th, it's really nice. Deseo not so much. ***Other Things to Do*** *Coba - A must see while you can still hike the largest pyramid at 130 feet. Breath-taking. Rent a car and do it on your own though. *Tulum - Tourist trap but worthwhile to visit for an hour *Akumal and Yal-Ku - Fantastic snorkel lagoon away from the crowds. Yal-ku was my favorite activity on this vacation. *Cenotes - Try to get at least one Cenote dive if you're open-water certified. It takes some real soul-searching but with trust, you will see unbelievable things. *Xel-ha OR Xcaret - Didn't go because they look like tourist trap wastes of time

Reviews.Title: “Can I live here? Please.”
Reviews.Author: AussieBecs
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Shangri La Caribe for 9 nights in October for our honeymoon. We had booked a partial ocean view, and were in room 3 Playa. Our room was on the ground floor of a three storey hacienda, located in the separate section of the hotel. We were close to the breakfast and dining room and also the second pool. We decided our room was probably the pick of the lot. The rooms are so well constructed, we didn’t have any noise from our neighbours or those above us. Also, the way our room faced we had the most amazing beach view – I would consider it beach front as opposed to ‘partial ocean view’! Our room had a massive verandah, half was covered and the other half was open to the sun, so good for drying clothes or sun baking. We had two hammocks as well as deck chairs and a table. The room was massive – fabulous king bed that was very comfy, a couch, desk and wardrobe with safe. The bathroom had a Mexican tiled basin, toilet and shower. Yes, the room was very simple and sparse. It took us a few minutes to get used to it. But, the clean, honest decoration was so welcomed and made me feel like I was in real Mexico – not a generic hotel that could have been anywhere. The hotel has a great bar and happy hour runs from 5 to 6pm – on the dot. Sensational pina coladas with a lot of rum! Two billiard tables and two table tennis tables as well. There was a TV in the corner but I only ever saw this on twice. The hotel had a good tour desk and internet room with 4 stations. Breakfast at the hotel was good – great selection of fruit and the hot cakes were particularly good. On Sunday and Wednesday nights there was a Mexican buffet – unbelievable guacamole! And the grilled fish was great too. I would be quite happy eating their guacamole for dinner every night. When the hotel did Mexican food they did it really well – when they tried to do other cuisine (i.e. spaghetti carbonara), it wasn’t so good. In the lobby they put up the menu for the coming days, so we could plan when we’d go out to eat on 5th ave. I recommend ‘Kool Fish’ near the hotel, walking up toward 5th ave. It’s next door to the mini mart that has been noted so many times (great variety of stock if you run out of anything!) Kool Fish did some nice seafood meals and it was a very chic setting. Locals were eating there, which is always a good sign. We didn’t find the need to get a cooler from the mini mart – some bars on 5th ave have MXN$19 beers, so that was cheap enough for us! Walking to 5th avenue was easy and very safe, though the store keepers trying to get you into their shops can get a little much. I was disappointed to see not one but two Starbucks along 5th, as well as a Burger King. We booked a Chichen Itza tour and liked Chichen Itza, but would not do a tour again and would much rather fork out more money for a taxi. The tour stopped off at a souvenir shop on the way, then stopped at a restaurant for dinner (ok, but not great food) when they then brought out kids to do some dancing that then requested tips. I’ve got no problem with that, but I didn’t get the feeling that the kids were seeing any of the pesos being provided. On top of this, as we were leaving, the restauranteur kept reminding us that gratuities were not included in drink prices – even though his drink prices were three times the price of anywhere else. We didn’t tip him after that. Chichen Itza was good – but do it by taxi and get a guide there. We did our Advance diving certification at the Cyan Ha dive shop, located on the hotel beach. The team there were very nice and took us to some great spots. If you do go diving, check to see if Tavo (‘the fish paparazzi’) will be filming you. $50 for a DVD of your dive and it’s all very well edited with great music. A fabulous keepsake. I love Playa Del Carmen and I love the Shangri La. I would definetly stay there again. After leaving the Shangri La we then had one night in Cancun before our flight and wish we hadn’t done this – the noise (telephones ringing, mobile phones, tvs, cars!) from Cancun was almost deafening after the serenity of PDC. If you want your all inclusive, tv, mini bar type of place all the best to you, but to me, this place epitomised what a honeymoon should be – just the two of us with a strong pina colada and the sound of waves crashing at night.

Reviews.Title: “A True Shangri-La”
Reviews.Author: UNC68girl
Reviews.Content: After visiting this hotel over 20 years ago and loving it the first time, I decided to return with my daughter and her husband. We can only say that the only thing that changed about the hotel was the growth of the area around it. Shangri-la was totally the same wonderful, clean, beautiful, non Americanized place to relax. In fact, everything including the food, cleanliness of rooms, friendliness of staff, and beauty of the beach, water was perfect. I only hope and pray it does not close next year and I have heard it might. There is no place like it. In fact, my daughter and husband cancelled a trip to Italy next year just so they can return for more true relaxation. The hotel gets my highest recommendation .

Reviews.Title: “A huge dissapointment- very over rated!”
Reviews.Author: firsttimeuser
Reviews.Content: I am sorry but all the other reviews on this hotel must have pretty low expectations of a resort that costs north of $300USD a night. I travel 150 nights a year and stay all over the world and found this hotel to be underwhelming at best and fraudulent at worst. What a con the website is; the pictures sucker you in and the experience is anything but a relaxing paradise. We arrived with our 2 month old baby at 2:00pm having flown from Australia (27 hours) and were told to sit in a filthy bar that had cigarettes in ash trays at every single table. We were rudely told that check-in was not until 3:00pm. When I enquired as to whether the room was ready they just pointed to the sign that said check-in was 3:0pm. They told us our room number so I walked down to see if indeed it was still being cleaned. The steam started to come out of my ears when I realised they were just making us wait for no reason at all. It was stinking hot and we were not in summer clothes having flown from cool weather at home. The rooms are a disgrace. A bed, shower and toilet is the only thing you get. We stayed in a beach front bungalow expecting a pretty impressive outfit based on the cost but the rooms are dirty, smell and the beds are like sleeping on timber slats. There is a day bed that has cigarette holes all through it and the cushion is so well worn that it may as well not be there. The hammocks have been ruined and are so uncomfortable that I sat on the wooden chair instead. The first impressions are not improved by the rest of the experience. After been very upset at the events of the first day we had a sleep and after taking care of the baby we went to the restaurant at 9:25pm (not that late for dining) but were told that the restaurant was closed. Indeed the advertised closing time is 9:30 but the all the food service had been cleared away and the staff were all sitting down eating their meal even thought there were still 5 or more tables with guests still eating..I was so mad that I walked (there is no phone in the room to call the front desk) the considerable distance to the front desk to speak to the manager. I was given the biggest brush off possible and my wife and I were forced to walk up the street in the dark to try and find somewhere to eat. The beach is nothing like the pictures on their web page. It is narrow, rocky and altogether very low grade. The water is dirty and smells strongly of sulphur (rotten egg gas). The pool is also massively over rated. It is small, old and not well kept. This resort has clearly dropped the bundle as based on other reviews it appears that they are planning on closing. Couldn't be sooner if you ask me.

Reviews.Title: “Peaceful Retreat with Great Service”
Reviews.Author: SavannahGal
Reviews.Content: This is my second trip to Shangri-La Caribe. I wanted to squeeze in another trip before it's anticipated April 2009 closure. I'm happy to say it doesn't look as likely that it is going to close as it did earlier in the year. The front desk said the final agreement was to have been signed in April 2008 with Marriott and it didn't happen. I hope that means it will remain open. This place is very peaceful and has great service. The food is okay (breakfast fantastic, dinner okay) and the rooms are fine. This place is not extravagant by any means but the bed and pillows are comfortable and we found it to be very charming. We LOVED the porches with hammocks. We were on the second floor so we felt totally secluded. During our stay, you would hear an occasional quite conversation but no rowdy shouting until an American wedding party arrived the day before our departure. The guests were probably 80% Europeans and 20% Americans during both my stays. Prior to the arrival of the loud wedding party, it was heavenly. We found the beach more interesting than the typical resort beach because a few locals use it for sunbathing. We enjoyed the people watching. They were beautiful and many seemed to just come out for a few hours of siesta. It is very unlike the typical American beach scene because people didn't bring chairs, sandtoys, boomboxes, umbrellas, food for an army, etc, etc, etc. They just came with a best friend or loved one, a sarong to put down as a blanket and a swim suit. The ocean was gorgeous and the sand was white and totally free of debris. You might want to bring snorkel and mask because there are lovely fish right off the beach in a rocky area. You can also rent them from the dive shop without fins for about $6 per day. The dive shop arranges snorkel trips. Ours was great. The sea was calm and like glass. The boat ride out was pleasant and the guide was enjoyable. We met several couples who were on their fourth, fifth, sixth trip to Shangri-La. That probably tells you all you need to know. We are not the type to keep going back to the same place but we will find it very hard to go to any other tropical beach as long as Shangri-La exists. I also can not say enough nice things about the staff. The same people have been there for years (one guy said 13 years) and they act like they remember you from last time. I remember all the guys in the restaurant from my trip 3 years ago. The service at all levels feels genuinely hospitable. You almost feel like you are a guest in their home.

Reviews.Title: “Shangri La Caribe is a perfect romantic getaway”
Reviews.Author: Scuba_Kim_8
Reviews.Content: If you want a quiet, romantic getaway, this is the place! There are no phones, alarm clocks, or TVs in the room. You can hear the waves crashing in at night if you have an oceanfront room (definitely recommended!) September was the perfect time to go to get away from the crowds. The resort was less than half full, which meant there was always a beachfront palapa available or chairs poolside. The food was pretty decent, especially the breakfasts. Be sure to bring or buy bug spray once you get there. There are "no see um" insects that hide in the sand, hammocks, and even your bed. As an outside adventure, we recommend renting a car and stopping at Akumal (the ideal Corona commercial). Chichen Itza was also worth the drive. Be sure to hire a guide! An added cultural experience is the Yoga class in the mornings across the street in the "jardin". Others have mentioned that this resort would be closing next Spring to make way for condos. However, the front desk informed me that it will be at least 2-3 more years before that happens. We hope to come back!

Reviews.Title: “Great location, a little too rustic for me”
Reviews.Author: wackyjack
Reviews.Content: Stayed Aug. 27 - 31. It was what I expected. The location and beach were absolutely beautiful. The room, not so pretty. VERY basic, 2 queen beds (pretty comfy) and a desk and 1 chair. Small bathroom, adequate. The A/C is over the bed, and with the fan on, my son got sick. Not good placement of A/C. Walk to the beach was only a few steps. Nice lounge chairs, pools are small but nice. Bkfst included, very good, dinner included, not as good. Salad and soup were fine, the entrees leave a little to be desired. Drinks at bar were very weak. Drove to 5th Ave., probably 2 miles... too much for me to walk. I think this is a good hotel for young, energetic people. I'm a 50 ish, large lady, and I debated as to whether or not I wanted to "rough it" (I like suites and pampering... not a toilet where you aren't supposed to flush the toilet paper). I tried it, husband and son liked it OK, I enjoyed my time, but would not stay again. Again, I think for a young, fit couple, who don't go in the heat of August, you would like it. Rather expensive though, $240 a night for 2. I would have expected a little more.

Reviews.Title: “We had a great time there!”
Reviews.Author: cati_travelling
Reviews.Content: While the very first impression was not fantastic, we ended up lovng the place. It is definitely not as upscale as the image they try to sell you through the website: the beach is public, the rooms are very simple, no room service and no spa. But it is a great hotel and excellent value for money. My top 8: 1 - great staff who is very prompt at solving any issue you may have 2 - fantastic beach with tons of space and locals who add a bit of flavour. also, for those who like walking on the beach, there is an endless path going north with hardly anyone 3 - very nice breakfast with good fruit selection and great eggs 4 - the scuba diving crew is very friendly and professional. Good place to get your certification 5 - both times we had dinner at the hotel the food was excellent 6 - Very nice people you can meet at the hotel 7 - very close to the center of Playa del Carmen, but far enough for you not to be in the middle of all the mess 8 - Fast wireless internet connection at reception I would go back if there weren't so many other places to visit in the world.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing View!”
Reviews.Author: soycrisps
Reviews.Content: We came to this resort after staying at a more high end, luxury resort and at first it seemed so rough and rustic. But after staying for three nights we loved it! We stayed in beach front palapa number 34P and our friends stayed in 35P, just like another reviewer! We arrived on a Sunday and were dismayed by how crowded the beach was, but it wasn't nearly as crowded the following days. I think the weekends are very busy and the public access point to the beach is right at the location of the resort. The view out our window was gorgeous and I woudl recommend anyone staying at this resort get an ocean front room. The included breakfast was delicious with a huge array to choose from and the dinners each night were great too. My picky husband thought the dinners were good, but not great, for what that is worth. If you don't like what is being served, you can ask for something else and they will give it to you if possible. The service was terrific and very impressive. There are guards on the beach constantly to keep non-guests off and this is the only hotel we stayed at that had an abundant supply of beach chairs under shaded palapas. The water is great, but there are a lot of people riding wave runners and boats, etc, so be careful if you go too far out in the water. The two hammocks on our shaded porch were a delight for our family and we had so much fun spending time on the porch. The room with two queen beds is huge, much larger than the room with a king size bed. We didn't use the pools at all here, but they looked very nice. Playa del Carmen has grown immensely and is overrun by condos and people these days. We loved this resort but could do wtihout all the people. There are topless women here and there on the beach, so if you have kids this is something to be aware of. We just explained it to our daughter before we got there and it wasn't an issue. Some people might not be so open about these things.

Reviews.Title: “Best hotel ever”
Reviews.Author: OsloWorld_traveler
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend and I went to mexico for a romantic vacation. The shangri la was the perfect spot. We are both young, but experienced traveleres. We have stayed in many "hige end hotels" but nothing evers has come close to this. If you've never been, don't miss the chance. Everyone is happy and friendly from the staff to the guest's and the local people. The on site dive shop is also very much recommended. Its in perfect distance to the town, airport cozumel ferry and the beach. I've never seen so nice beaches, and the water is to die for. This was the best vacation ever thanks to the Shagri la caribe

Reviews.Title: “Rustic Paradise!”
Reviews.Author: PAF
Reviews.Content: My wife and I enjoyed our second stay at Shangri-La Caribe this past June. We had celebrated our ten year anniversary at Shangri-La back in July 2005 and loved it even more on our 2008 stay. We were in the process of planning a trip to Kauai when I found out the Shangri-La Caribe was slated for demolition in June of 2009, to make way for more condominiums. We adjusted our plans and headed to Playa del Carmen. We stayed in the Aventura Section of the resort in dieciocho playa; our previous stay was in seis playa. Both are penthouse rooms; seis playa was our favorite, though dieciocho playa is also wonderful. The breeze off the sea in the Aventura Section is very enjoyable, no need for A/C at night. I have heard the rooms further in from shore do not get the cool breeze in the evenings. If you are looking for a king size bed the only way to guarantee you get one is by reserving a penthouse suite; it is well worth the extra cost. The price of the room includes breakfast and dinner, a fantastic deal when you consider the beauty of this place. We thought with the closing of the resort in 2009 the staff might not be as attentive, but the service was as professional as we remembered. Rueben was an exceptional waiter who welcomed us every evening and took care of our every need. On our last night he provided us with an amazing table decorated with flowers shells and linen backed chairs. Ask for Rueben you will not be disappointed. Dinners at La Loma are very good; I would not say many places in Playa are great, but the dinners offer a variety of entrees, with a buffet thrown in every now and then (Mexican Fiesta Night was a lot of fun). The mosquito’s bit our legs the first night, but a little bug spray (Family Off) kept the little guys at bay the rest of our stay. Breakfast includes a buffet with fresh fruits, juices, pastries, meats, in addition to the made to order egg entrees. We had dinner in town at Playasia one night. Very romantic atmosphere (cenote runs right through the middle of the restaurant) with tables set up in tree house like arrangements. Food was very good food. The beach at Shangri-La is still the best and one of the biggest in Playa. The chairs are spread out with your own private palapas, they don’t cram beach chairs 20 deep like most all the resorts we passed on the beach. Security keeps vendors from coming up constantly, but you can buy a cup of fresh fruit from a vendor if you just give them a nod. This place is rustic; no phones or TV’s in the rooms and that is the appeal of the resort. It is not an all inclusive filled with tons of people and that is the reason why we love it. You will find a very international guest list; many of the guests are from Europe in addition to a good number of Americans. If you like the all inclusive resorts this is not the place, but if you want a truly unique and relaxing vacation this is it. The town has crept northward just steps away from the resort. I have talked to people who remember Shangri-La being surrounded by jungle with no condos in sight. Speaking of condos, it is hard to imagine that this place will be bull dozed to make way for more of the awful looking condos that have taken over the coastline of Playa, especially to the north. A little bit of Lagniappe: There are several convenience stores up the road, Calle 38, but the one to hit is Super “El Campeon”. Little Elliot will put your drinks in the cooler and fill it with ice; great service. You can pick some wine and beer to enjoy on your balcony, along with any necessities you might have forgotten.

Reviews.Title: “Great spot for a honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: kdeepost
Reviews.Content: Overall, we loved the Shangra-la. In the first half hour of our arrival we were put off by the room we were given as it was located in the back of the property where the cool winds do not blow, resulting in a n atmosphere that smelled like decaying wet neoprene--yuck. With my husband's support, I was ready to leave to find a new hotel, but the front desk worked with us, until they finally satisfied us by moving us to a palapa closer to the ocean, one that got fresh air and was not musty at all. From there our honeymoon took off and we settled in to a slower speed, enjoying the cold beers at the bar, the warm sun and sand, and rollicks in the waves caribe. We lived in "doce b," 12B, for 5 nights and enjoyed it. The rooms are sparsely decorated, but roomy. We loved our porch, which doubled our space and made our stay so much more enjoyable. Being on the top floor had it's pros and cons, but I'd say it had more pros than cons--it felt much roomier with steeply vaulted ceilings and provided more privacy to the newlyweds, but may have let in some tiny gnat-like bugs that bite. We were never sure if we were bit by virtually invisible bugs in our room, or by bugs somewhere else, but I was definitely bitten on my side many times. These bites were tiny, but numerous. All the staff at the hotel was super friendly. The food was great. And we did learn that the Marriot bought the proprerty and the one neighboring and will be tearing it down to built a new one of their own in 2009. Bummer. So go to the Shangra-la Caribe now if you can. The beach is beckoning.

Reviews.Title: “Retro and Rustic Paradise”
Reviews.Author: montstress
Reviews.Content: My sister and I stayed at this hotel over the long 4th of July weekend. We loved the rustic elegance and outdoor atmosphere of this "beach village resort" --the sand-covered paths connecting the bungalows, the outdoor bar with rope swings, and the beautiful gardens around every corner. We also enjoyed the communal vibe and getting to meet so many people from all over the world. We ran into many of the same people at the happy hour bar, the tv/game room, or at breakfast every day (the fresh fruits, juices, and the mexican-style eggs were to die for!) We only ate dinner at the hotel one night, which was very good, but we wanted to try some of the many restaurants in town the other nights (don't miss Alux, in a dry cenote in an underground cave, recommended by Boli, the wonderful concierge.) We loved the fact that the rooms had no phones and no tvs. Isn't that what you are coming here to get away from? I can see if you stayed longer or were travelling with kids you might appreciate having a cooler in the room, as others have suggested, but since we were only there 4 days we didn't need it. It was like going back in time to the simplicity of enjoying the sunny weather, the beautiful surroundings and people you are with. There are two pools which are fairly basic, but they seemed to be more than adequate for families with young children. We were more than happy to walk the extra 10 steps to be in a loungechair in front of the caribbean, so the pool was not a big draw for us. This resort is one of a kind, with it's mexican-tiled bathrooms, palapa roofs, and log railings on all the balconies. It will be a real shame if they tear this place down for more boring condos with no character. Don't miss a massage in the hut on the sand. The girls we had were awesome. We thoroughly enjoyed the authentic Mexican charm and hospitality, but don't come here if you require room service, nintendo or cabana boys.

Reviews.Title: “Had high expectations....”
Reviews.Author: RoaryCat
Reviews.Content: ....and they were exceeded! After researching numerous hotels for our trip to Playa del Carmen I decided on Shangri-La Caribe based on the hotel website, price and the reviews on here and I could not be happier with the decision to stay here. Location was good, end of the beach, about a 10 minute walk to the heart of 5th Avenue. Check-in was very efficient as the check-in document was already prepared and the bellhops were very attentative to detail, showing us everything about the room (including the safe) and setting up two hammocks for us, and everyone who worked there was extrememly friendly and helpful. The room was very clean, roomy and well decorated and the entire property was immaculate. We considered skipping out on one of the dinners that were included in the price, but after our first meal decided not to: food was very good and service was amazingly propt. Breakfast was awesome, a huge buffet with rolls, fresh juice (I can't drink regular orange juice now!) fresh fruit, oatmeal and sausages, in addition to the mexican egg dishes for order. Oh yeah, 2x1 happy hour at the bar every night from 5 to 6. I certainly hope the rumors this property is being bought out and closed is just a rumor as when we return to Playa we don't want to stay anywhere else.

Reviews.Title: “I Wish I Could Have Stayed Longer!”
Reviews.Author: BigGreen00
Reviews.Content: My fiancee and I recenlty attended the wedding of a friend, which was on-site at the hotel. But we headed down a few days early to get some extra vacation time, and were there a total of five days. I can't even begin to describe how bummed we were when we returned on Sunday. This hotel is everything the previous reviewers have advertised it to be. Quaint, romantic, well laid out, clean, full of amenities, etc. etc. etc. The room rates are insanely affordable, especially given that they include breakfast and dinner. We figured it'd be the standard fare continental breakfast, and a dinner buffet with cold refried beans, dried-up tortillas and chewy fajita meat. WRONG WRONG WRONG! The breakfast had everything you could want -- from pastries, fruits and yogurt, to made-to-order french toast, pancakes, eggs and omelettes! And the dinners were just as good -- each night featured some sort of fresh seafood, as well as great tasting chicken, beef and vegetarian dishes. As one who likes to eat, I was anything but disappointed. We stayed in the Caribe section of the resort and had our own single-story bungalow that was maybe a 30-meter walk to the beach. The room was very clean and well decorated. Yes, the beds are hard compared to what we Americans are used to, but they are hard like a Tempurpedic "memory foam" mattress and not stiff like a board. I personally loved them. The air conditioning worked like a charm for the few times our ceiling fan wasn't enough to cool us. What else...the pool areas (2) are both very cute and provide a nice freshwater alternative from the beach and warm waters of the Gulf. It was very windy on two of the days, but the interior pool area was so well sheltered by the tall palm trees and bugalow rooms that we were able to spend our entire day outdoors with zero wind. SO NICE! The hotel also has an on-site dive shop, which is heaven if you are a scuba diver (or snorkler). I don't think I've ever been able to stroll 10 meters out of my hotel room door, make a reservation for a dive, and then wade out straight out into the water to board the boat! No long drives to some far away pier, no annoying long boat ride to a far away scuba site. It really could not have been more convenient and the dive staff was SO incredibly friendly. Finally, we loved the actual location of the hotel within Playa. As I'm sure you know, Playa is not nearly as developed as its neighbor to the north. But there are those who think that even its famed 5th Avenue is already overdeveloped (e.g. there are now TWO Starbucks locations). Fair enough. But the best part about the Shangri-La is that it's a few blocks away from the very northern point of the 5th Avenue strip. So you have the total peace and isolation of this amazing resort, and yet you're only a 10min walk to the main commercial strip of Playa if you want to do any shopping, go out to bars, etc. Okay, I've already written 10x what I intended. Can you tell I love this place?!! I would go back tomorrow if I could take the time off work again. On a final, sad note, I too have heard that the hotel was sold recently and will be closing in 2009. So all I can say is get there while you can! It kills me to think that all those cute little casitas and those amazing trees will be bulldozed to make room for some Cancun-like behemoth.

Reviews.Title: “Go while you still can!”
Reviews.Author: megaflip
Reviews.Content: Shangri-La is the best place to stay in Playa del Carmen if you want to have an all-inclusive hotel (breakfast and dinner only) and still be in walking distance to Playa del Carmen. It is nice to be at a hotel that is not secluded and away from the city. My husband and I got married in May at the Shangri-La Caribe Resort. We had a wonderful stay and wedding at this fabulous hotel. It is on a beautiful beach with lounge chairs and palapas. The water is a gorgeous shade of blue and it is not difficult to swim there. The food was excellent! Every night there was a different themed meal. The staff was very nice and helpful. The rooms were neat and clean. Rumor has it that it will be closing in April 2009, not because it is a bad hotel, but because it was bought out by some people who are going to build condos on the property. If you are even considering this place then you have to go because it is excellent and it is the last place in Playa that has a Carribean feel to it. You won't regret your decision!

Reviews.Title: “Simply put....Paradise”
Reviews.Author: MuEagles79
Reviews.Content: Learned about this resort from a friend who traveled there for a wedding back in 2005. He described it as paradise. We were not disappointed. I reserved a Penthouse room in the Aventura section of the resort. Literally we were about 100 feet away from the sea. The water is beautiful as is the sand/beach. Very European(topless is not uncommon) and very relaxed. Very few children running around and almost all were well behaved. We were one of the few American couples at the resort during our stay. The staff was incredible. Helped up set up transportation to the ruins and XCaret. We highly recommended XCaret for a day. If you are up for some adventure, rent a taxi for the day($250 USD for 2 people) and you can do Tulum, Coba, & Chichen Itza in one day. It makes for a long day(8am-7:30pm) but what an incredible experience that just isn't available if you have to ride on a tour bus. Restaurant was consistently good, not great, for breakfast and dinner(included in the room charge). Remember to tip your waiters! 5th Avenue is a great way to spend an afternoon/evening...plenty of decent restaurants(Italian food is the special here!) and nightclubs/bars. Bring you bargaining shoes as every vendor is willing to negotiate a price. All in All....we couldn't have had a better time...thanks Shangri La!

Reviews.Title: “Great Place -Book while you can!”
Reviews.Author: surfbecca10
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the hotel(really a bungalow) in May and loved the place. It is a large property, yet you feel like there are only a few others at the resort. Your accomidations are small bungalows with thatched roofs, we had two queen beds, and a good size bathroom with a shower. No tub. The only minor problem was the beds are rather hard for this American. As the pictures show, all bungalows had hammocks that were perfect for the afternoon siesta! The meals were really good and a wide variety. The pools rarely had more than 4 poeple in them. I always could find a chair at the beach, and our section was not very crowded. The hotel is located in a great area with a convenience store nearby and the popular 5th Ave about 3 blocks away. Apparently the Marriot organization has bought the property and it will close in April 2009. Such a shame......small intimate properties like this are rare in Playa anymore. So go while you can!!

Reviews.Title: “Best Beach in Playa”
Reviews.Author: Stachiq
Reviews.Content: We just returned from Shangri La Caribe yesterday. We could not be more pleased about our choice! The service was friendly, prompt but not pushy. We booked an Ocean View room in the Caribe section. This section has some stand-alone rooms with thatched roofs. We loved the covered front porch outside of our room, complete with hammocks. I think the beach in front of Shangri-La is the best in Playa. If you can't book here, consider Las Palapas next door. It too has a great beach. We were definitely within walking distance to Quinta Avenida (Fifth Avenue), the main drag with restaurants and shops in Playa. The food - particularly the breakfasts - were wonderful.

Reviews.Title: “Thumbs Up!”
Reviews.Author: 24fan
Reviews.Content: We (fiancé & I) enjoyed our week-long stay @ Shangri La Caribe. The hotel is located on a great stretch of beach where you can walk for long distances in either direction. We had a room in the Pueblito section (garden view) in a two-unit casita. The rooms are fairly spare. No TV, no phone, no radio not even a clock and if you need one, be aware there are no hair dryers. That said, the room was clean and functional. Lots of closet space, a king size bed, good bathroom counter space with an open shower on one side and water closet on the other. Good air conditioning and ceiling fan. Screens on all the windows with little inside shutters you could open or close as you wish. All the rooms feature a balcony with a pair of hammocks that were great for lounging. The rooms have a safe, but be aware, while heavy it is not attached to the wall, however, we did not have any concerns regarding security. Our room was a one-minute walk to the beach, which features loungers and a group of palapas. We secured a palapa and pair of chairs and small table each day. I was usually at the beach by 8:30 - 9:00 and had no problems. There are two small pools on the property. We did the pool only one day when the weather was cool and windy at the beach but much warmer a few steps inland at the pool. Shangri La is small (85 rooms) and is not the place to go if you are looking for a wild party scene. It is very laid back and relatively quiet. There is a small bar with happy hour 2 for 1 from 5:00 – 6:00 each day and that is when the bar is the busiest. At the bar there is a game room under a large palapa with a couple of pool tables and ping-pong tables. My fiancé and played pool a couple of nights around 9:00 or 10:00 and there might have been one or two other couples around at the bar--very quiet. The game room also has Wi-Fi. The location of Shangri La was excellent. A one block walk away from the water puts you at the north end of the main street (Fifth Ave). On the corner is a small market where we picked up soda and beer. The gift shop at the hotel is very minimal and doesn’t sell sodas or much in the line of snacks. From that corner it was a relatively short walk to the main shopping, dining, nightlife area on Fifth Ave. We a walked it every day and typically ate somewhere differently each night. We usually took a cab back to he hotel and from the main square the price varied between $3 – $5 for a cab ride back. Shangri La is modified AI with breakfast and dinner included. Can’t say much about the dinners cause we never ate there. Breakfast was fine. There was a buffet with fruits, breads, cereal etc and hash browns and sausage each day and there was also a menu where you could get eggs cooked to order or pancakes, French toast etc. The staff at Shangri La was very friendly and very hard working. The breakfast crew was large and really hustled to make sure everyone was taken care of. The bar staff worked really hard at happy hour to make sure everyone was waited on quickly. Bottom line is this is a great place if you are looking for quiet and relaxing. Not so good if you want a party scene or want to be in the middle of the action. That said it isn’t difficulty to find excitement in the Fifth Avenue area, which is really a short distance away.

Reviews.Title: “Great location-stops there”
Reviews.Author: Liza9999
Reviews.Content: Great location,such a shame. Management just not there. They appear very understaffed. Most of the staff works hard and are nice. Exceptions are one person at front staff and the bartenders, who were absolutely rude at times. If you go to Playa don't miss Yal-Ku for snorkling, Coba and beachfront bar (next to Blue Parrot. Great salsa band there--dancing on the beach!. Forget Starbucks, the coffee shop right up the street is locally owned & much better. Buy items off the main street or when traveling. All shops have the same mechandise...what's up with that???? You can go to another beachfront location and get a lot more for the money

Reviews.Title: “Very relaxing”
Reviews.Author: kiboko
Reviews.Content: I realy enjoyed this hotel. We had half board even usualy I don't like it. Food was very good and it was even a very good deal compare to all the prices outside in town. Not far from the main shopping and going out area of Playa but still quite enough to enjoy it. Beach very nice and not to crowded.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful beach and very relaxing”
Reviews.Author: Jaklen98
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the hotel 10 days in the Pueblito section. The room we stayed in was 58B, on the second floor. We like this because you have the thatched roof and our balcony was large. I had a hard time booking, I wanted the Caribe section but was told that they were all booked. I made our reservations about 3 months in advance, so I would recommend to make yours asap. I would definately stay there again. It is very relaxing, no tv or radio or phones We ate dinner in town almost every night. One night we did eat at the hotel and it was very good. The waiters really hussle to take everybody's order and try to get everything out in a timely manner. We have been going to this area of Mexico for the last 14 years and just love it. The beaches are beautiful and white and the ocean is that beautiful turquoise and the blue of the sky is breathtaking. We really like the people because they are very friendly. If anyone would like some recommendations as far as hotels and restaurants, please contact me.

Reviews.Title: “Windy But Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: MarylandGypsy
Reviews.Content: My husband and I spent 6 nights at the Shangri-la Caribe during President's week. We were in a beachfront casita, #34 Playa. It was larger than the beachfront one we had 3 years ago in the Caribe section. Even though the hotel will be replaced after the 2009 season (so we were told at check-in when we inquired, having read on Trip Advisor that it had been sold), everyone who worked there was very pleasant. The beach was much wider than in 2005, desite Hurricane Wilma and last year's storm which landed on Cozumel. So we were very happy that the resort was in excellent condition. One thing that is less pleasing now, however, is the fact that the beach is quite crowded with those non hotel guests who enter this public beach by way of the road which serves as a beach access. Whereas before the land behind the hotel was undeveloped, now it has several new condos. People camped right in front of our casita on more than one occasion, and used the shady spots under the palms and palapas. When told to move by the security, they moved only a foot ot two forward. The food was as good as ever. We liked the 3 buffet nights. There is so much to choose from, and most items are very good. I would describe it as just plain tasty, not gourmet. The servers are very polite and seem happy with their jobs. I understand from a guest who has been returning for 17 years, that many of them have worked there for that length of time. The buffet breakfast is wonderful because the eggs and breakfast meats are all cooked to order, and the servers take the order. The choices include all kinds of egg dishes, as well as some Mexican specialties. No waiting in the omelet line while everything else gets cold at this hotel! If you want a laid back, relaxing vacation right on a lovely beach, but don't crave Ritz Carlton type pampering with marble, truffles, and nightly chocolates, then this is the place for you.

Reviews.Title: “Best on the Beach”
Reviews.Author: stevesmallhomes
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed there for a week and we really didn't want to leave. Not just because we were going from 85 degrees back to 25 degrees, but because the hotel is such a relaxing place. This appears to be the only place left on the beach that's not a huge resort. The rooms are spread out in small thatch roof villas connected by sandy paths. We had an ocean view room, just steps back from the ocean front. Great being so close we could just pop up to the room from the beach to pee! The first room we were given had no view at all and 2 double beds. We talked to the desk, and they said they couldn't move us until after the second night. The place was booked solid, so we understand it was difficult to move us, but it was worth the wait-the room we moved into had a comfortable king bed, a fantastic view, great A/C, deck, hammocks, and privacy. The beach is beautiful and well supplied with palapas and lounge chairs. It is a public beach, and it got pretty crowded with locals on Sat and Sun, but there was never a shortage of space as 3 security guards made sure said palapas and chairs were only occupied by guests. On the weekdays, the beach was lively, but not crowded. Around lunchtime, a waiter goes around the beach taking orders for food and drinks which are delivered quickly. We brought a soft sided cooler and took a daily walk to the "mini-super" about 2 blocks away to stock up on water, ice and beers , thus keeping our bar tabs down. There are 2 pools which usually had lots of kids around, so we pretty much stuck to the beach. Breakfast and dinner are included, and both were good. Breakfast has a great spread of fresh fruit, pastries, cereals and fresh squeezed juices, plus you can order eggs any way imaginable, pancakes, french toast, etc. Fill up and you can just have a light lunch (not included, but we usually just got an order of fries). Dinner is included, and the food was excellent. Not a buffet, except Mexican night, and includes soup, app, entree and dessert. The menu, which changes daily, is posted at the front desk. We don't eat beef, pork or chicken and there were a few days we looked at the menu ahead of time and saw we wouldn't have options, but usually there is an excellent fish option. There are lots of places easily within walking distance if you don't care to eat at the resort, as you are only a few blocks from 5th. The best, however, is not even that far. La Cueva de Changa is just up Calle 38. Amazing food in a garden setting. Service is slow, but relax, you're on vacation. The hotel may be closing in a year or so to make room for condos, so if you're thinking about it, better act fast, I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Great place!!”
Reviews.Author: bates4
Reviews.Content: We just came back from Shangri- La last week & we would highly recommend it. The setting was beautiful, the staff very friendly & such a great location. We had the breakfast (which was included) every morning at the hotel but were able to walk to 5th Avenue in the evenings for dinner. It was quiet during the day & lively at night. A perfect match for us!!

Reviews.Title: “Paradise”
Reviews.Author: Sunlover94
Reviews.Content: We just got back on 2/16 from Playa del Carmen and we absolutely loved our stay! It was wonderful to be completely disconnected for the week and just spend our time in paradise. We with the intension of spending most of our time on excursions. However, once we arrived we loved the hotel so much we ended up spending most of our time at the resort. We loved spending our days at the beach and our evenings sipping cocktails in our hammocks. This was a faboulous retreat and we're so sad to hear that the hotel will be demolished.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful stay”
Reviews.Author: AquaCaribe
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a week at Shangri-la Caribe and give it our highest recommendation. The grounds are beautiful, the beach and waters clean and clear, and the staff were very friendly and helpful. We stayed at a spacious penthouse unit in the Playa section with hammocks on our porch and views of the beach. There is a plentiful breakfast included and dinner. We ate at restaurants on Quinta Avenida a few evenings but the dinners on-site were good as well. Being able to easily walk to Quinta is another benefit of the hotel's location. The property is indeed being converted to condos but will still be available for vacation stays through April 2009.

Reviews.Title: “Posh Robinson Crusoe”
Reviews.Author: Grether
Reviews.Content: This was everything we hoped for. Limited crowd, beautiful beach, and great accommodations. After we made reservations, two more couples joined us. My wife and I had a beachfront bungalo 3C. It was the best. We were almost among the beach chairs and it was 30 steps to the water. Each morning at sunrise, there was a team of people raking the beach and the pathways. It was pristine. Our room was immaculate. The windows were invisible. Restaurant service was excellent, especially Ivan. The concierge service was helpful and ready to solve issues. My kudos to Bolli and Tatiana. I enjoyed great massages. I believe the massuese was Nedhi. Very relaxing. However, my wife had a male masseur that was a dissappointment. Upon discussion with the concierge, that fee was refunded even though we did not demand it. That was impressive customer service. Be sure to request a female masseuse. We did not aim for an all-inclusive, so having meals included was not one of our priorities. We planned to eat dinner in town. However, we changed our mind and ate EVERY dinner at Shangri-la because we enjoyed it. There was live entertainment at least 3 nights that was great. This was our first visit and regret to learn that the hotel will only operate for another year. It has a personality that will be lost. If we can, we will return before they close. Unlike trips to other locations, we were not able to use credit cards for everything. Plan to take lots of cash and an ATM card.

Reviews.Title: “Loved this place!!!”
Reviews.Author: debminn
Reviews.Content: We just got back home on Friday, Feb 15, and wish we were back at the Shangri-La. We were a little worried that the service wouldnt be quite up to snuff because we have heard they are tearing the place down to build condos, but everything was great. The service was wonderful. By the third day our favorite waiter Ivan, knew what room we were in and that means a lot I think. The room was clean, basic, but that's what we expected. The balcony was great, but my husband did have a hard time with no TV in the room. The beach is great, not at all busy down on that end of town. If they were not tearing the place down I would stay here again if I went back to Playa del Carmen. I do not think we will be back for quite some time because it is so busy on 5th Ave now, it's just insane. We do not like that many people around us all the time while we're on vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Great place!!!!”
Reviews.Author: marina_from_belgium
Reviews.Content: We just came back from 8 days at Shangri-La in the Caribe Section Room 33A Garden View Bottom floor and had a great time. We were traveling with our 10-month-old son to a tropical destination for the first time and were more than a bit nervous about the dinking water - bottle washing - formula storage - etc. We had a wonderful time. I will not repeat what others said below about the beauty of the site (amazing), the quality of the food ( very good), etc. I thought the staff was very nice, especially the restaurant staff who constantly played with baby while working really hard. The bartenders: not super friendly but doing their jobs. The reception: upon checking the dark-haired lady was not all that friendly either, but she warmed up every other time I talked to her after that. I guess we can't be in a great mood all the time. There were many families with young children. They have high chairs and cribs. We had to call the pediatrician ( hotel visit) on the 3rd day, as each morning baby woke up with more red dots on his face and hands, fearing it was chicken pox or the like. Must have been a bug in the crib, which we exchanged after the $80 bill of the quite useless doctor, who appeared to be right out of high school and completely baffled as to what happened to baby. He had a stethoscope and nothing else ( no thermometer, stick to look in mouth, or "thing" to look inside ears, nothing!) so since baby was fine, we ended up finding it quite comical. The dots cleared up slowly after swapping the crib and baby was fine. Bugs - yes, but only around baby's food, not randomly crawling around. Having to do everything out of a sink with no counter space, not spilling anything was a bit of a challenge, so we did see ants ( small and medium size) and then a few mosquitoes, which I suspect were coming out of the shower drain? So take mosquito repellent, better safe than sorry, but nothing to be scared of. For cheap food and drinks: buy them up the street. There is a small store one block up and a bigger store ( like a 7-eleven type store) called OxxO that sells styrofoam coolers ( the the left above a fridge machine when you get in - not very visible) and ice for 25 pesos and has an ATM. Everyone takes dollars but gives change in pesos. For lunch -- ate in town once ( pricey), once up the street at cueva del chango (very good, cheap and original place), and at the hotel restaurant 3 times ( once there, once took it to go back to the beach and once a waiter walked by and gave us a menu right on the beach), once in cozumel. Oh yeah, we took the ferry to Cozumel. Since the walk to the ferry is a good 45 minutes power trot, we took a cab - about $5USD - very cheap. Ferry was $14USD round-trip/person, about 35 minutes trip. Cozumel was fine but with baby we couldn't do what we would have normally done: rent scooter, go on snorkeling trip, etc. but it was still fun. They have hair dryers at the lobby desk on demand. The first few days were very windy with big waves and not as warm as expected - we usually go at the end of May. The water in pool was chilly and the ocean was definitely refreshing. The wind slowed down and then the weather was just perfect. We had a tiny bit of rain here and there, usually early morning but not enough to see if you get up past 7am. People got up early. Of course, so did we. Breakfast starts at 7:30am but they had coffee machines at the bar and by the restaurant much earlier. People do keep their chairs really early so beware. There were always some available but you had to hunt them down. Try by the pool by the breakfast restaurant, there seemed to be more availability there. I didn't reserve our seats at first since I am kind of against that. One day we got to the beach at 8am and all the 100 chairs had towels on them but only about 15 people were there. Some people reserve chairs all day long but only show up for about an hour per day, which I think is not right. That day, I found 2 empty chairs and moved over 2 "reserved" chairs so we could use their palapa for shade. Sorry, but with baby, shade was a "must". They showed up in the afternoon and did not say anything. After that, I, too, started "reserving" our spot before breakfast, but didn't feel so bad because we did stay there all day long and actually used them. By mid-afternoon, many people seemed "done" with the beach. The sun would go down on the beach by 4:30pm, then most seemed to go shower or relax in the hammocks ( which were great!) and at 5pm it was time for cheap and potent margaritas for happy hour. The wait until 7pm sometime seemed long since it was dark by 6pm, which also marked the end of happy hour :-) My husband got a massage and seemed satisfied. We brought our snorkeling gear, not too much to see ( compared to other places like Akumal or Belize) but still fun if waves allow, just head for the dark patches (reef). People watching was great. Many people strutting their stuff. Well, I think that's all I can think about. I wish we were still there, and we'd go back in a second!

Reviews.Title: “S.O.S. Save our Shangri La!”
Reviews.Author: justmyopinion_7
Reviews.Content: 2 friends and I stayed at the Shangri La Caribe for a week in January. As others have stated, the grounds are beautiful and the location perfect. The food was more than satisfactory. Even the dinners, which many have critisized, were much better than I was expecting. My friends, who both work in upscale Montreal restaurants, found the dinners very good as well. I really don't know what people expect for a dinner that's included in the room price but I have eaten in expensive "fine dining" restaurants that I did not enjoy as much. It was most definitely the nicest spot that we saw in Playa del Carmen. It truly is a shame that this hotel will be demolished to put up condos, which are a dime a dozen around there. I wish the new owners would rethink their plans and realize how unique and inviting this hotel is and be proud to keep it the oasis it is. But, the almighty dollar beckons I guess. I really hope that I can make it back there before it closes and enjoy it one more time. Playa del Carmen is nice but it is the Shangri La Caribe that I would return for.

Reviews.Title: “Overall Fantastic Resort in a Gorgeous Setting”
Reviews.Author: AngelaColumbus_OH
Reviews.Content: The resort is a gorgeous property. The grounds and buildings are all beautiful. 2 pools, large hot tub, nice bar with swings and 2 pool tables and 2 ping pong tables. We had, I think, the best bungalow, 31P. It was about 30 yards from the ocean, right on the beach. Some of the other beachfront units were too close to the water and the traffic of the pedestrians, runners, and families who plunk down on the beach. We had 2 hammocks on the porch, as I think all of the units had. There was a wonderful breeze on the beach, so we never had to use our air conditioning. Away from the beach it was hot though, so I'd guess units not on the beach did use the A.C. My husband and I thought the food was good. Breakfast (included) was a beautiful fruit buffet, 2 types of fresh juice, sausages, hash browns, breads, teas, coffee, and your choice of omelets, eggs, french toast, pancakes and mexican breakfasts as well. The lunches (not included) were OK. The Mexican food is real Mexican food - it is not Tex-Mex or something you'd find at Chipotle or Chile's. So it may not look like you expect it too. This was the way we found it to be on or off the resort. We also thought the dinners (included) were fine. The grilled fish was especially good. Some nights there was a buffet and some nights 2-3 choices (i.e. pastas, pork, fish). I thought the drink prices were fine ($3-4 US) for a beer, about $4-5 US for a cocktail. Happy Hour with 2 for 1 on most drinks from 5-6. The location was great, at the north end of Playa, right on the beach. To walk to town on the beach was about 20-25 minutes and about a 10-15 minute walk on the city streets. It's about 3 blocks to 5th avenue, the main street, which is a fun pedestrian walkway. We walked back through town by ourselves at night to the hotel and felt quite safe. The down side -- the staff. We finally found a bartender with personality, after about 5 days. The rest of them just weren't real friendly, even with tips. Wendy at the front desk was downright rude, on a couple of occasions. We asked the female concierge if she could recommend a few good restaurants in town. Her reply: "I don't know, I never go down there." Really! We are saddened that it's going to close. We were told it was closing in April 2009. We would love to go back and spend time at this beautiful resort. Except for the staff, it was a slice of heaven and I'd highly recommend it, especially if you like laid back, small resorts. Although there must have been several hundred people there, we never saw many people, at the pools, at the meals. I guess that's the beauty of the layout. We didn't have any problems with the orange beach towels, by the way. We'd leave ours out on the beach lounge chairs to hold our spot all day and they'd always be there when we got back. Also, do lock everything in the safe. When we checked in, we heard them telling people they'd had some problems with theft. We never had any problems with that or with any bugs in the bungalow.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful stay!!!!!!!!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: Ancor71
Reviews.Content: Date: Jan 26 - Feb 2 We just returned from a great week stay at the Shangri-la and can safely say that our trip was more than what we expected. The palapa style theme was an experience we will never forget.
